episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Rebecca Moore
episodes.description: Rebecca Moore is the former Chair of the Department of Religious Studies at San Diego State University. Moore is co-editor of Nova Religion: The Journal of New and Emergent Religions, and served on the Steering Committee of the New Religious Movements Group of the American Academy of Religion for six years. She has published extensively on Peoples Temple, her interest stemming, in part, from the loss of three family members in the mass deaths in Jonestown, Guyana, in November 1978.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Fielding McGehee
episodes.description:
Documenting and Archiving Peoples Temple and Jonestown
Fielding M. McGehee III
Research Director, The Jonestown Institute

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Leigh Fondakowski
episodes.description:
Leigh Fondakowski, Head Writer of The Laramie Project, has been a member of the Tectonic Theater Project since 1995.

She is an Emmy nominated co-screenwriter for the adaptation of The Laramie Project for HBO, and a co-writer of The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later. Her play, The People's Temple, has been performed under her direction at Berkeley Repertory Theater Company and The Guthrie Theater, and received the Glickman Award for Best New Play in the Bay Area in 2005.

Her first work of non-fiction, Stories of Jonestown, was published by the University of Minnesota press in Fall 2012.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Stanley Nelson Lunch Talk
episodes.description:
Stanley Nelson, Emmy-winning filmmaker and MacArthur
"genius" Fellow, is co-founder and Executive Director of Firelight Media, which provides technical education and professional support to emerging documentarians. He is also the co-founder of the for-profit documentary production company, Firelight Films.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Jordan Vilchez
episodes.description: Jordan Vilchez, a member of People's Temple as a teenager, was in Georgetown, Guyana on November 18, 1978, but her sisters and nephews died in Jonestown. She was on the Planning Commission and is familiar with many inner workings of the organization.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Julia Scheeres
episodes.description:
Julia Schrees, a journalist by trade, has written for Los Angeles Times, The New York Times, The Guardian, and many other publications. Her first book, Jesus Land-a memoir about growing up in a strict Christian environment with an adopted black brother-was a New York Times and London Times bestseller.

Schrees is the author of A Thousand Lives: The Untold Story of the People's Temple.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Stephan Jones
episodes.description: Stephan Jones, the only biological child of People's Temple leader Jim Jones, escaped the Jonestown events along with members of a People's Temple basketball team, who were in Georgetown that day. Jones lost most of his family and community. He was 18 at the time.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Tim Carter
episodes.description:
Tim Carter, a member of the People's Temple who survived Jonestown on November 18, 1978 by going on a final mission for Rev. James Warren Jones with his brother, Michael Carter, and Michael Prokes. He fought in Vietnam for the United States.

He lost his wife, Gloria Rodriguez Carter; his son, Malcolm Carter; his sister Mary Theresa "Terry" Carter Jones; his brother-in-law Lew Eric Jones; and nephew on November 18, 1978.

episodes.title: Griot Institute, February 6, 2013 - Jonestown Reconsidered  Student Response
